answers.text:
Two years ago I led and facilitated the  successful merger of a free-standing, private non-profit merger with our volunteer fire department in our 5,200 person island community.  Happy to share our experiences with you.

answers.text:
Newport News, VA and Hampton VA are currently negotiating shared service agreements.  While not a merger, we are trying to right size and take advantage of service overlap and duplication.  Feel free to contact me if you want more information.

answers.author: Jon Altmann
answers.text:
There is very little, if any, movement to privatize EMS from public sector.  The threats of this occurring of late have been in political subdivision who are coming up on labor contract expirations with their unionize employees in a collective bargaining situation.  There are many different model of public/private partnerships in EMS and you may feel free to contact me about a recent presentation I prepared updated this for a major Colorado community.

answers.author: Leonard Matarese
answers.text:
Before even considering the structure of the Fire/EMS system, it would be worthwhile to gain a clear understanding of the realities of the EMS system that has evolved over the past 30 years in this country. Many of the commonly accepted premises of the EMS system turn out to be based upon false assumptions or outdated models. "Getting there faster saves more lives", "the more paramedics the better the outcomes" and "all ALS systems are the best design" all turn out to be false assumptions when viewed through an evidence based analysis. 
The best document to review on these issues is the White Paper produced by the University of Oklahoma Medical School which I have attached. 
This is a real eye opener, written by nationally recognized emergency physicians / researchers that is a must read for anyone managing an EMS system. For example, the research shows that having all firefighters trained as paramedics is probably a bad idea in most systems and also explains why private ambulance services with dynamic staffing can produce better outcomes at lower costs. We are seeing many local governments, in light of these realities, reconsidering delivery of EMS, particularly transport, thru the fire service. 
Chief Joe Pozzo, the Center for Public Safety Management, Senior Manager for Fire/EMS and I will be discussing this paper and other alternative delivery systems for fire/EMS in our upcoming ICMA University Audio Conference on February 20th. For information on attending this session go to
http://learning.icma.org/store/seminar/seminar.php?seminar=16483

author: Jared Hershberger
text: I am doing a class project and would like to find a city/county/department manager that has been faced with the decision of privatizing EMS, merging EMS with existing fire department(s), or staying as is.  Would someone please point me in the right direction? Thank you!
title: EMS: Privatization & merging with Fire Department(s)
